**Chapter Twenty-One**
The supreme virtue acts without striving, not seeking through scrutiny.
The lower virtue acts through effort, its function unceasing.
When the upper is sealed, it is called "being";
when the lower is sealed, it is called "non-being."
The non-being serves the upper,
where the numinous virtue resides.
These two apertures follow the method—
the qi of Metal also requires long endurance.

The supreme virtue and lower virtue refer to *Li* as the heart, which dwells above,
within which the Jade Fluid may become the Reverted Elixir, benefiting humanity—hence it is called supreme virtue.
*Kan* as the kidneys dwells below,
within which the Golden Fluid may also become the Reverted Elixir, benefiting humanity—hence it is called lower virtue.
To gather the Jade Fluid, one need not rely on cultivation.
To gather the Golden Fluid, one cannot do without the furnace and bellows—
without cultivation, it cannot be attained.
When sealed and obstructed,
the Jade Fluid is closed and enters the Mysterious Throat (the Mysterious Female),
then rejoicing in its return.
The Golden Fluid is closed and enters the Tail Gate,
then rejoicing in its absence of leakage.
This is the distinction between "being" and "non-being."
The Golden Fluid ascends from below to become the *po*;
the Jade Fluid descends from above to become the *hun*—
hence it is said the numinous virtue resides.

**Chapter Twenty-Two**
Know the white, guard the black—
white is Metal’s essence, black is Water’s foundation.
The numinous brightness comes of itself.
Water is the pivot of the Dao, its number named One.
The beginning of yin and yang,
mysteriously containing the Yellow Sprout.
The master of the five metals,
the Northern River Chariot.
Thus lead appears black without,
yet harbors golden splendor within—
clad in coarse cloth, bearing jade,
outwardly a madman.

Mysterious is the color of Heaven;
Yellow is the color of Earth.
Within pure *Qian*, yang reaches its extreme and generates yin,
whereupon *Li* arises.
From *Li* emerges *Xun*, then *Gen*, extending to *Kun*—
this is what is meant by containing the Yellow Sprout.
When a person receives the embryo,
it originates from the father’s essence,
transforming to generate the five viscera—
thus among the five viscera’s metals, the kidneys preside.
Preserved in the kidneys, it becomes Metal.
When the golden essence takes flight,
the River Chariot is employed to transport it—
the River Chariot is the qi ascending from the North to reach the Muddy Pellet.

**Chapter Twenty-Three**
Metal is the mother of Water,
the mother conceals the child’s embryo.
Water is the child of Metal,
the child dwells in the mother’s womb.
The Perfected One is most wondrous,
seeming to exist, seeming not to exist.
Like a great abyss with tangled kelp,
now sinking, now floating.
Withdrawing, they disperse,
each guarding its own domain.

Metal can generate Water—hence it is called the mother of Metal.
Metal resides within *Kan*—hence it is said to conceal the child’s embryo.
*Kan* is the kidneys; though the kidneys are Metal’s child,
they first dwell within the mother’s womb before this body exists.
Yet when first concealed in the mother’s womb,
if not for the Perfected One’s presence within,
how could it attain such wondrous subtlety?
Viewed from its subtlety, one takes it as being;
yet as a mere clod of earth, one takes it as non-being—
yet the myriad things are all contained within.
Like sinking and floating in the great abyss,
it cannot be fathomed by ordinary perception.
When it withdraws and disperses,
the five viscera, six bowels, hundred bones, and nine orifices
are all thereby completed.

**Chapter Twenty-Four**

chunks.original_text: 采之类白，造之则朱。 炼为表卫，白裹贞居。 方圆径寸，混而相拘#35。 先天地生，巍巍尊高。 人身上为天，下为地。 当其未有是身也，则受父之精，而后能有此天地，故精气为先也。 《易》以乾为首，坤为腹是也。 方圆径寸，乃丹田也。 金在坎中，其色白。 方其操之也，不得乎南方之朱，安能以造成金丹哉？ 亦犹父之精叉得乎母之血，然后可以尽生成之义。 是故白居乎裹以为贞，而离为表卫以炼於外，故能相拘於方寸之中矣。 盖纯阴之中，一阳复而为坎，然后化为震，为兑，以至於为乾。 纯阳之中，一阴生而为离，然后化而为巽，为艮，以至於为坤。 是则坎离者，先天地而生，故能巍巍然，如是之尊高也。 右第二十五章 旁有垣阙，状似蓬壶。 环匝关闭，四通踟跚。 守御密固#36，关绝奸邪。 曲阁相通#37，以戒不虞。 可以无思，难以愁劳。 神气满室，莫之能留。 守之者昌，失之者亡。 动静休息，常与人俱。 垣阙，肾部之官也。 曲阁，尾问关。 戒不虞者，防梦寐而或泄也。 惟能平日无邪思，则可矣。 动之则失静，而休息则存矣。 右第二十六章 是非历藏法，内视有所思。 履行步斗宿#38以．日辰。 阴道厌九一，浊乱弄元胞。 食气呜肠胃，吐正吸外邪。 昼夜不外寐，晦朔未尝休#40体日疲倦，恍惚状若痴。 百脉鼎沸驰，不得清澄居。 累土立坛宇，朝暮敬祭祠。 鬼物见形象，梦寐感慨之。 心欢意喜悦#41延期。 遽以夭命死，露腐#42。 举措辄有违，悖逆失枢机。 诸术甚众多，千条有万绪#43违黄老，曲折戾九都。 历举旁门小法，使后学知所戒也。 右第二十七章 明者省厥旨，旷然知所由。

**Chapter Twenty-Five**

Its essence resembles white; when refined, it becomes vermilion.
Tempered as external defense, white enfolds the steadfast core within.
Square and round, a mere inch in span—intermingled, they constrain one another.
Born before Heaven and Earth, majestic and exalted.

The human body’s upper part is Heaven; its lower part, Earth.
Before this body existed, it received the father’s essence,
and only then could this Heaven and Earth come to be—thus essence and qi take precedence.
The *Book of Changes* takes *Qian* as the head and *Kun* as the belly—this is the same principle.
Square and round, a mere inch in span—this is the cinnabar field.
Metal resides within *Kan*, and its color is white.
Yet if one does not obtain the vermilion of the southern quarter,
how could one complete the golden elixir?
It is like the father’s essence requiring the mother’s blood
to fulfill the meaning of generation and transformation.
Thus white abides within as the steadfast core,
while *Li* serves as external defense to refine it without—
hence they constrain one another within a single inch.
For within pure yin, one yang revives to form *Kan*,
then transforms into *Zhen*, into *Dui*, and finally into *Qian*.
Within pure yang, one yin arises to form *Li*,
then transforms into *Xun*, into *Gen*, and finally into *Kun*.
Thus *Kan* and *Li* are born before Heaven and Earth,
and so stand majestic and exalted.

**Chapter Twenty-Six**

Surrounding walls and watchtowers—shaped like Penglai’s isles.
Encircling barriers, sealed gates, four passages winding and slow.
Guard and defense are tight and firm, barring all wickedness.
Curved galleries connect, ever vigilant against the unforeseen.
One may remain free of care, yet not succumb to weariness.
The chamber brims with spirit and qi—none can detain them.
Those who preserve it thrive; those who lose it perish.
In movement and stillness, rest and activity, it ever accompanies the person.

The walls and watchtowers are the palaces of the kidney region.
The curved galleries are the Gate of the Tailbone.
Vigilance against the unforeseen means preventing leakage in dreams.
Only by maintaining no deviant thoughts in daily life can this be achieved.
Movement leads to loss of stillness, while rest and activity preserve it.

**Chapter Twenty-Seven**

These are the misguided methods of internal alchemy:
inward gazing with deliberate thought,
treading the steps of the Dipper and lunar lodges,
reckoning days and celestial stems.
The yin path suppresses nine and one, muddling and toying with the primordial womb.
Ingesting qi gurgles in the intestines and stomach;
exhaling the upright, inhaling external perversities.
Day and night, never sleeping outwardly;
from new moon to dark moon, never ceasing.
The body grows weary and exhausted, the mind dazed as if deranged.
The hundred vessels seethe and race, unable to settle into clarity.
Piling earth to erect altars, morning and evening offering reverent sacrifices.
Ghosts and spirits manifest forms, dreams and sleep stir emotions.
The heart rejoices, the mind delights—prolonging the appointed time.
Yet suddenly, life is cut short in death, exposed and rotting.
Every action goes awry, perverse and contrary to the pivotal mechanism.
Such arts are myriad, with a thousand strands and ten thousand threads—
all deviating from the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, twisting and turning against the Nine Capitals.

These are the sundry heterodox minor methods, by which later learners may know what to avoid.

**Chapter Twenty-Eight**

The discerning grasp its meaning, perceiving clearly its source.

chunks.original_text: 勤而行之，夙夜不休。 服食三载，轻举远游。 跨火不焦，入水不濡。 能存能亡，长乐无忧。 道成德就，潜伏俟时。 太一乃召，移名#44。 功满上升，膺录受图。 言《参#45》之书，能用心以明之， 则金丹之匕曰无出乎是。 右第二十八章 《火记》不虚作，演《易》以明之。 偃月法#46，白虎为熬枢。 汞日为流珠，青龙与之俱。 举束以合西，魂魄自相拘。 上弦兑数八，下弦艮亦八。 两弦合其精，乾坤体乃成。 二八应一斤，《易》道正不倾。 铢有三百八十四，亦应卦爻之数。 上弦铅八两，下弦汞八两，一两二十四铢，合十六两言之，有三百八十四铢，应六十四卦三百八十四爻也。 故 曰：乾坤体乃成。 白虎者，坎中之银也。 非假偃月炉以煎熬之，终莫能得是宝也。 谓之枢者，既得是宝，则欲其自曲阁之道以运之，使至泥丸而后止。 其次，则离为日，流珠自玉池而出，而青龙亦与之同涂而至。 苟能以汞龙自玄牝门而入，则龙与虎合，故日举束以合西也。 虎为魄，龙为魂，则自相拘於炉鼎之内矣。 右第二十九章 金入於猛火，色不夺精光。 自开辟以来，日月不亏明，金不失其重，日月形如常。 金本从月#47朔旦受日符。 金返归其母，月晦日相包#48藏其匡郭，沈沦於洞虚。 金复其故性，威光鼎乃嬉。 金，即坎中液也。 得离火以炼之，愈坚而愈莹。 日，即离也。 月，即坎也。 坎、离不以金火，既施於用，而遂失其明。 而金亦常不失其重者，生生而不穷也。 日月之形常如是者，其源本至坚固也。 虽然，惟金火施为金丹之用，则可以如是。 苟为不然，则《黄庭经》所谓叶去树枯失青青，气亡液漏非已形者，又不可与此同日语也。 《经》 曰：初正则终修，干立末可持。 此之谓也。 大抵金常生於坎，亦随日魂之消长，而为盛衰也。 故朔日一受日符，则愈生而愈盛。 自阴符生而至於晦，则月魄化为坤矣。 故金返归其母，乃坤之土为金之母也。 故虽然阴极则．阳生。 故月於晦夜已包乎日之魂，如坎之孕于坤中也。 但其明未着於外，而特隐藏於匡郭之中．，而沈沦於洞虚之内也。 然当此之时，金丹得以复其故性，而其明愈炽矣。 右第三十章 子午数合三，戊己号称五。 三五既谐和#49，八石正纲纪。 呼吸相贪欲#50，伫思#51为夫妇。 黄土金之父，流珠水之母。 水以土为鬼，土镇#52水不起。 朱雀为火精，执平调胜负。 水盛火消灭，俱死归厚土。 三性既合会，本性共宗祖。 坎为水，一数也。 离为火，二数也。 合之而为三矣。 坎管戊，而离管己； 戊己属土，五数也。 故为三五。 二者，夫妇之义，故和谐。 八石者，《黄庭经》以为八素琼是也。 谓自初八而至十五，八日所探之丹资也。 二者相贵为夫妇，爻须呼吸以求之。 盖出日则呼，入月则吸。 黄土脾液也，故能生金肺液也。 流珠谓太阳流珠，亦肺液也，故能生坎水。 然坎水之为物，当阴符一至，则阳气索灭藏，体魄化为坤。 坤属土，故水为之镇，而微弱不振矣。 非得火精而为之调和，安能以返其魂哉？ 惟当阴盛火消之余，故此水终为土所制，而无生意矣。 然谓之水盛，而不言阴盛者，盖自下弦而至三十日，以时则属乎冬，以方则象乎北，故日水盛。
chunks.translated_text:
Persevering in its practice, rising early and retiring late without rest,
After three years of ingesting the elixir, one ascends lightly and roams afar.
Striding through fire yet unscorched, entering water yet undrenched.
Able to appear, able to vanish—ever joyful, free from care.
The Dao perfected, virtue accomplished, one withdraws to await the moment.
The Great One then summons, and one’s name is transferred.
With merits fulfilled, one ascends on high, receiving the register and the chart.
The book of *Can* declares: those who apply their minds to fathom it
will find no elixir beyond the golden cinnabar.

**Chapter Twenty-Eight**

The *Fire Record* was not composed in vain; it expounds the *Yi* to clarify the process.
The crescent-moon method: the White Tiger serves as the pivot of refinement.
Mercury is the flowing pearl of the sun, the Green Dragon accompanying it.
Raising the sheaf to meet the west, soul and spirit naturally bind.
The upper crescent, *dui*, holds the number eight; the lower crescent, *gen*, also eight.
When the two crescents merge their essence, the body of *Qian* and *Kun* is formed.
Two eights make one *jin*; the Dao of the *Yi* stands upright, unwavering.
A *zhu* contains three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*, corresponding to the number of hexagrams and lines.
The upper crescent yields eight ounces of lead; the lower crescent, eight ounces of mercury.
One *liang* equals twenty-four *zhu*; together, sixteen *liang* total three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*,
matching the three hundred and eighty-four lines of the sixty-four hexagrams.
Thus it is said: the body of *Qian* and *Kun* is formed.
The White Tiger is the silver within *Kan*.
Without the crescent-moon furnace to refine it, this treasure can never be obtained.
It is called the pivot because, once this treasure is secured,
it must be circulated along the winding path until it reaches the Muddy Pellet and halts.
Next, *Li* becomes the sun, the flowing pearl emerging from the Jade Pool,
while the Green Dragon travels the same path to arrive.
If one can guide the mercury-dragon through the Mysterious Female’s gate,
then dragon and tiger unite—hence "raising the sheaf to meet the west."
The tiger is the *po*; the dragon, the *hun*—thus they bind within the crucible.

**Chapter Twenty-Nine**

Gold enters fierce fire, yet its color does not fade nor its luster dim.
Since the dawn of creation, the sun and moon have never lost their brightness,
nor has gold forfeited its weight, nor have the sun and moon altered their form.
Gold originally receives the solar tally at the new moon’s dawn.
When gold returns to its mother, the moon at dusk envelops it,
hiding its frame and sinking into the cavernous void.
Gold regains its original nature, and the cauldron’s radiance rejoices.
Gold is the fluid within *Kan*. Refined by the fire of *Li*, it grows ever firmer and more luminous.
The sun is *Li*; the moon, *Kan*.
Without the interplay of metal and fire, *Kan* and *Li* would lose their brilliance after use,
yet gold never loses its weight, for it is ceaselessly regenerated.
The sun and moon retain their form because their source is utterly steadfast.
Yet only when metal and fire are employed for the golden elixir can this hold true.
Otherwise, as the *Huangting Jing* says—"leaves fall, the tree withers, losing its verdure;
qi perishes, fluids leak, and the body is no more"—such cases cannot be spoken of in the same breath.
The *Classic* states: "Begin with rectitude, and the end will be well-ordered; establish the stem, and the branches may be grasped."
This is the meaning.
In general, gold is born from *Kan* and waxes and wanes with the sun’s spirit.
Thus, at the new moon, it receives the solar tally and grows ever more abundant.
From the birth of the yin tally to the dark of the moon, the lunar *po* transforms into *Kun*.
Thus gold returns to its mother, for *Kun*’s earth is gold’s mother.
Yet when yin reaches its extreme, yang is born.
At the dark of the moon, the moon already enfolds the sun’s spirit,
like *Kan* gestating within *Kun*.
Though its light is not yet visible externally, it lies concealed within its frame,
submerged in the cavernous void.
At this moment, the golden elixir regains its original nature, and its brilliance blazes ever brighter.

**Chapter Thirty**

The numbers of *zi* and *wu* combine to make three; *wu* and *ji* are called five.
When three and five harmonize, the eight minerals form the guiding principle.
Breathing in desire, contemplation unites them as husband and wife.
Yellow earth is gold’s father; the flowing pearl, water’s mother.
Water treats earth as its ghost; earth subdues water, preventing its rise.
The Vermilion Bird is the essence of fire, balancing victory and defeat.
When water prevails, fire is extinguished, and both perish, returning to the fertile earth.
Once the three natures converge, their original essence shares a common ancestor.
*Kan* is water, the number one; *Li* is fire, the number two.
Together they make three.
*Kan* governs *wu*; *Li* governs *ji*. *Wu* and *ji* belong to earth, the number five—hence "three-five."
The two embody the relationship of husband and wife, thus they harmonize.
The eight minerals are the eight luminous jades of the *Huangting Jing*,
referring to the elixir ingredients gathered from the eighth to the fifteenth day.
The two are prized as husband and wife, their union sought through breath.
Exhaling when the sun rises, inhaling when the moon appears.
Yellow earth is the fluid of the spleen, thus it generates the metal of the lungs.
The flowing pearl is the sun’s flowing pearl, also the lung’s fluid, thus it generates *Kan*’s water.
Yet when the yin tally arrives, the yang qi vanishes and hides, the body’s *po* transforming into *Kun*.
*Kun* belongs to earth, so water is subdued and grows faint, unable to stir.
Without the fire’s essence to harmonize it, how can its spirit be restored?
Only when water prevails and fire wanes does earth ultimately dominate, leaving no vitality.
Yet it is called "water’s prevalence" rather than "yin’s prevalence,"
for from the lower crescent to the thirtieth day, the season is winter, the direction north—hence "water prevails."

chunks.original_text: 三性共祖宗者，盖人之始受胎也。 以父精为主而化成五藏，故五藏之五行皆宗於水也。 右第三十一章 巨胜尚延年，胡麻也。 还丹可入口。 金性不败朽，故为万物宝。 术士服食之，寿命得长久。 土游於四季，守界定规矩。 金砂入五内，雾散若风雨。 黑蒸达四肢，颜色悦泽好。 发白皆变黑，齿落生旧所。 老访复丁壮，耆妪成姥女。 改形兔世厄，号之日真人。 坎中之金制为还丹，终不败朽，故万物之中最为宝也。 土游四季者，谓坎、离二卦管戊己，而布六十卦於三十日之内，分为四时。 故一月夺一年之气候。 坎金离砂自入炉鼎之外，则用之以养内丹。 其金砂之入五藏，不啻如云雾之散，如风雨之润，故能需蒸四肢以反老成童者，岂不有本於此哉？ 右第三十二章 胡粉投火中，色坏还为铅。 冰雪得温汤，解释成太玄。 金以砂为主，禀和於水银。 变化由其真，终始自相因。 欲作服食仙，宜以同类者。 植禾当以黍，覆鸡用其子#53。 以类辅自然，物成易陶冶。 鱼目岂为珠，蓬蒿不成价。 类同者相从，事乖不成宝。 是以燕雀不生凤，狐兔不乳马，水流不炎上，火动不润下。 胡粉乃以铅为之，今投於火而复为铅。 冰雪自水而结之，投於温汤亦化为水。 是犹金丹亦藉砂和水银为之，及火灭而复其本性，以见物之有本，而终始不能以自坏也。 修炼之士，其可外坎离而别用其心也哉？ 右第三十三章 世问多学士，高妙负良才。 邂逅不遭遇，耗火亡货财。 据按依文说，妄以意为之。 端绪无因绿，度量失操持。 梼冶羌石胆，蕾买母及誉磁。 硫黄烧豫章，泥顿．相炼飞。 鼓下□五石铜，以之为辅枢。 杂性不同类，安肯合体居。 千举必万败，欲点反成痴。 侥幸讫不遇，圣人独知之。 稚年至白首，中道生狐疑。 背道守迷路，出正入邪蹊。 管窥不广见，难以揆方来。 智不足以明是理，切莫妄意以有为。 妄意而为之，反为识者之见哂。 右第三十四章
chunks.translated_text:
The Three Essences Share a Common Origin—this refers to the moment when a person first receives the embryo. The father’s essence serves as the foundation, transforming to form the five viscera, and thus the Five Phases of the five viscera all take water as their origin.

**Chapter Thirty-One**
Sesame prolongs life—this is *huma*.
The returning elixir may be ingested.
Gold’s nature does not decay, thus it is the treasure of all things.
Those who consume it as alchemists gain long life.
Earth wanders through the four seasons, guarding boundaries and setting rules.
Golden sand enters the five viscera, dispersing like mist or wind and rain.
Black vapor reaches the four limbs, restoring radiance and luster to the complexion.
White hair turns black again, fallen teeth regrow in their original place.
The elderly regain youthful vigor, the aged crone becomes a maiden.
Transforming form to escape worldly calamity, one is called a Perfected Person.
The gold within *Kan* is refined into the returning elixir, never decaying—thus it is the greatest treasure among all things.
"Earth wanders through the four seasons" means that the two trigrams *Kan* and *Li* govern *wu* and *ji*, distributing the sixty-four hexagrams across thirty days, dividing them into four seasons.
Thus, one month seizes the qi of an entire year.
Beyond the crucible and furnace, *Kan*-gold and *Li*-sand are used to nurture the inner elixir.
When golden sand enters the five viscera, it disperses like clouds and mist, moistening like wind and rain.
Thus, it steams the four limbs, reversing age to restore youth—how could this not have its foundation here?

**Chapter Thirty-Two**
Lead powder cast into fire loses its color and reverts to lead.
Ice and snow, warmed by hot water, dissolve into the Great Mystery.
Gold takes cinnabar as its essence, harmonizing with mercury.
Transformation arises from its authenticity, beginning and end naturally following one another.
To become an immortal through ingestion, one must use substances of the same kind.
Plant millet with millet, hatch chicks with eggs.
Supporting nature with like kinds, things form easily as if molded.
Fish eyes are not pearls, thistles have no value.
Like attracts like; discordant matters do not yield treasure.
Thus, swallows do not birth phoenixes, foxes and hares do not nurse horses.
Water does not flow upward in flames, fire does not moisten downward.
Lead powder is made from lead—cast into fire, it reverts to lead.
Ice and snow, formed from water, melt in warm water to become water again.
So too the golden elixir relies on cinnabar and mercury; when fire ceases, it returns to its original nature.
This reveals that things have their roots, and beginning and end cannot destroy themselves.
How could those who cultivate the elixir disregard *Kan* and *Li* and employ their minds elsewhere?

**Chapter Thirty-Three**
The world abounds with scholars, gifted with lofty talent.
Yet chance meetings elude them, wasting fire and squandering wealth.
They rely on texts, imposing their own interpretations.
Threads lack cause, measures lose control.
They smelt malachite and quartz, purchase mother-of-pearl and lodestone.
They burn sulfur with camphor wood, knead clay and refine it into flying ash.
They smelt the five metals with copper beneath the bellows, using them as auxiliary pivots.
Mixed natures of different kinds—how could they willingly unite?
A thousand attempts lead to ten thousand failures; what they seek to transmute turns to dross.
Fortune never favors them, for only the sage truly understands.
From youth to white-haired age, doubt arises midway.
Turning from the Dao to cling to delusion, leaving the straight path for crooked byways.
Peering through a tube, their vision is narrow—how can they gauge what lies ahead?
If wisdom is insufficient to illuminate this principle, do not rashly act on whim.
To act on whim invites the scorn of those who know.

*Kun* belongs to earth, so water is subdued and grows faint, unable to stir.
Without the fire’s essence to harmonize it, how can its spirit be restored?
Only when water prevails and fire wanes does earth ultimately dominate, leaving no vitality.
Yet it is called "water’s prevalence" rather than "yin’s prevalence,"
for from the lower crescent to the thirtieth day, the season is winter, the direction north—hence "water prevails."

chunks.original_text: 若夫至圣，不过伏羲，始画八卦，效法天地。 文王帝之宗，结体#56演爻辞。 夫子庶圣雄，《十翼》以辅之。 三君天所挺，迭兴更过时#57。 优劣有步骤，功德不相殊。 制作有所踵，推度审分铢。 有形易忖量，无兆难虑谋。 作事令可法，为世定诗书。 素无前识资，因师觉悟之。 皓若寨帷帐#58，瞋目登高台。 《易》书之作，乃成於三圣之手，岂易明哉？ 况金丹之旨，有体乎《易》，其微妙隐奥，尤过乎是。 右第三十五章 《火记》六百篇，所趣等不殊。 文字郑重说，世人不熟思。 寻度其源流，幽明本共居。 窃为贤者谈，曷敢轻为书。 若遂结舌疮#59，绝道获罪诛。 写情着竹帛，又恐泄天符。 犹豫增叹息，倪仰缀斯愚#60。 陶冶有法度，未忍悉陈敷。 略述其纲纪，枝条见扶练。 六百篇者，盖一年除二月、八月息火，而一月每用六十卦，十个月总有六百卦也。 幽明：幽谓天地之道，明谓人也。 右第三十六章 以金为堤防，水入乃优游。
chunks.translated_text:
As for the utmost sages, none surpass Fuxi, who first drew the Eight Trigrams, modeling them upon Heaven and Earth. King Wen, imperial ancestor, structured the forms and composed the line statements. The Master, near-sage and hero, supplemented them with the *Ten Wings*. These three lords, Heaven’s chosen, arose in succession through the ages. Though their excellence followed in steps, their virtue and power did not differ in kind. Their creations built upon what came before, their calculations weighed each fraction with care. What has form is easily measured, but what leaves no trace is hard to contemplate. Their deeds set patterns for emulation, their works established the *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents* for the world. Lacking innate foreknowledge, they relied on teachers to awaken their understanding. Bright as one who parts the curtains, they opened their eyes and ascended the high terrace. The *Book of Changes* was thus completed by the hands of these three sages—how could it be easily understood? How much more so the subtle principles of the Golden Elixir, which embodies the *Changes* in its very essence? Its mysteries and hidden depths surpass even these.

---

The *Fire Records* of six hundred chapters share a common aim. Though their words are earnestly expounded,世 people do not ponder them deeply. Tracing their origins, the obscure and the manifest originally dwell as one. I speak here for the wise—how dare I treat these writings lightly? Yet if I seal my lips in silence, I risk severing the Way and incurring punishment. To commit my thoughts to bamboo and silk might reveal Heaven’s tally. Hesitant, I sigh in uncertainty, gazing up and down in foolish attachment. The art of refinement has its methods, yet I hesitate to lay them all bare. I shall outline only their essential framework, that the branches may be seen through the guiding threads. These six hundred chapters correspond to a year’s ten months of firing—excluding the second and eighth months of rest—with each month employing sixty hexagrams, totaling six hundred. "Obscure" refers to the Way of Heaven and Earth; "manifest" refers to man.

---

With metal as the embankment, water enters and flows freely.

chunks.original_text: 金计十有五#61、水数亦如之。 临炉定铢两，五分水有余。 二者以为真，金重如本初。 其三#62遂不入，火二#63与之俱。 三物相合受#64，变化状若神。 下有太阳气，伏蒸#65须臾间。 先液而后凝，号曰黄举焉。 岁月将欲讫，毁性伤寿年。 形体为灰土，状若明窗尘。 十五者，谓十分取其五也。 乃自初一至十五日，则自上弦之日探金也，故下日水五分。 水，乃玉池神水也，亦然。 其三不入者，乃一日作四分分也。 金水皆取一分，而余二十三日不入也。 火二者，阴阳二艮加喊－必么火也。 金，即坎中之阳。 水，即离中之阴，乃玉池清水也。 岁月将欲，讫者在十二月，则坤卦之讫在亥月也。 在一月，则讫于坤乙三十日也。 在一日，则讫于亥时也。 火之阳魂，皆於此而灭，故日毁性。 一日夺一小年，一月夺一中年，十二月夺一大年，皆至於年终则伤其明也。 惟其毁伤如是，则月之形体有类乎灰土，而状亦何异於明窗尘哉？ 右第三十七章 梼治并。
chunks.translated_text:
With gold reckoned at fifteen and water’s measure the same,
Before the furnace, fix the weights—five parts water in excess.
These two become the true essence, gold’s weight as in its origin.
The third then does not enter; fire’s dual aspect joins with it.
Three substances unite in reception,
Transforming with a power divine.
Beneath lies the qi of Great Yang,
Steaming and seething in but a moment.
First liquid, then congealing,
It is called the Yellow Ascent.
As years and months draw to their close,
Nature is undone and lifespan harmed.
The form becomes ash and dust,
Appearing like dust on a bright window.

The fifteen refers to taking five from ten.
From the first to the fifteenth day,
One gathers gold at the waxing half-moon—
Thus below it is said “five parts water.”
Water is the numinous water of the Jade Pool, likewise measured.
The “third that does not enter” divides one day into four parts:
Both gold and water take one part,
While the remaining twenty-three days do not.
“Fire’s dual aspect” refers to the two *gen* trigrams of yin and yang, the fire of necessity.
Gold is the yang within *kan*,
Water is the yin within *li*, the clear water of the Jade Pool.

“As years and months draw to their close”:
In the twelfth month, the end lies in the *kun* hexagram’s close at the *hai* month.
In one month, it ends on the thirtieth day of *kun-yi*.
In one day, it ends at the *hai* hour.
The yang soul of fire perishes therein—thus it is called “nature undone.”
Each day steals a minor year,
Each month steals a middle year,
Twelve months steal a great year,
All reaching their term by year’s end, harming one’s clarity.
Only when thus undone and harmed
Does the moon’s form resemble ash and dust,
Its appearance no different from dust on a bright window.

chunks.translated_text:
Entering through the Crimson Gate,
Seal its junctures fast,
Ensuring all is whole and firm.
Beneath, the blazing fire spreads,
Its roar ceaseless day and night.
First, the civil method is applied;
In the end, the martial is arrayed.
Observe with utmost care,
Discerning the shifts of cold and warmth.
Through the twelve cyclical nodes,
At each completion, attend anew.
When qi is spent and life near its close,
Rest and death claim the hun and po souls.
The hue shifts, turning deep violet—
Resplendent, the Reverted Elixir forms.
Ground to powder, shaped into a single pellet,
The *daogui* is most divine.
Prayers and treatments combine here,
Where all medicines converge.

The Crimson Gate refers to the crucible.
Seal it whole and firm, allowing no leaks,
Then kindle the fire to refine it.
Begin with the civil, end with the martial,
Attending to cold and warmth.
When the fire’s measure completes one cycle,
Qi is exhausted, the flame spent,
The hun fades, the po returns—
And the Elixir is achieved.
What is this if not divine?

chunks.original_text: 推演五行数，较约而不繁。 举水以激火，奄然灭光明。 日月相激薄； 常在晦朔问。 水盛坎侵阳，火衰离昼昏。 阴阳相饮食，交感道自然。 月本无明，藉日以为明。 惟月至晦，则变纯坤体矣。 而坎阳已孕于中，故常当晦朔之交，而月或侵阳，故有举水激火之说。 坎侵阳，离昼昏，乃月食日也。 此亦交感自然之谓也。 右第三十九章 名者以定情，字者绿性言。 金来归性初，乃得称还丹。 吾不敢虚说，仿效圣人文。 古记题龙虎，黄帝美金华。 淮南炼秋石，王阳加．黄芽。 贤者能持行，不肖母与俱。 古今道犹．一，对谈吐所谋。 学者加勉力，留念探思惟。 至要言甚露，昭昭不我欺。 名者，有实之可名也。 字则表而出之，又涉於无名也。 有者，魄也，其情也。 无者，魂也，其性也。 惟金丹至火灭，乃得复其性而成丹矣。 虽然金丹之旨亦须留心精审，则厥旨自明，非有隐也。 周易参同契注卷上竟 #1因未得其他版本以参校，故暂以俞瑛《周易参同契发挥》四库本（后文简称《发挥》本）校勘其经文。 #2『犹上御者，准绳墨，执衔辔』，《发挥》本作『犹御者之执衔辔，有准绳』。 #3『规』，原作『规』，据《发挥》本改。 后文相同处径改不注。 #4『晦爽』，《发挥》本作『昧爽』。 #5『为证』，《发挥》本作『为征』。 #6『之际』，《发挥》本作『之时』。 #7『媾』，《发挥》本作『构』。 #8『化黄包』，《发挥》本作『统黄化』。 #9『混沌』，《发挥》本作『浑沌』。 后文同。 #10『当』，《发挥》本作『称』。 #12『冠婚』，原作『昏冠』，据《发挥》本改。 #13『咸』，原作『成』，据其文义改。 #14『恒』，原作『怕』，据其文义补正。 后文相同处径改不注。 #15『讪伸』，《发挥》本作『讪信』。 #16『萌』，《发挥》本作『初』。 #17『庚受』，《发挥》本作『受庚』。 #18『丁受』，《发挥》本作『受丁』。 #19『气』，《发挥》本作『无』。 #20『东北丧其朋』，《发挥》本作『束方丧其明』。 #21『阳气』，《发挥》本作『易象』。 『八卦布列曜，运移不失中』，在此两句之前，《发挥》本把《后序》中的『象彼仲冬节』一节调於此，其由详见俞玫《周易参同契释疑》。 #22『证』，《发挥》本作『征』。 后文有相同处不再注明。 #23『时令』，《发挥》本作『节令』。 #24『卦节』，《发挥》本作『卦变』。 #25『用』，《发挥》本作『周』。 #26『可得』，《发挥》本缺『得』字。 #27『魁柄』，《发挥》本作『魁杓』。 #28『俯仰』，《发挥》本作『仰俯』。 #29『合』，《发挥》本作『含』。 #30『讥刺』，《发挥》本作『刺讥』。 #31『受正』，《发挥》本作『处正』。 #32『之知』，《发挥》本作『知之』。 #33『金气』，《发挥》本作『有无』。 #34『退而』，《发挥》本作『进退』。 #35『相拘』，《发挥》本作『相扶』。 #36『密固』，《发挥》本作『固密』。 #37『相通』，《发挥》本作『相连』。 #38『履行步斗宿』，《发挥》本作『履斗步呈宿』。 #39『以』，《发挥》本作『次』。
chunks.translated_text:
Extending the reckoning of the Five Phases,
Concise yet not cumbersome.
Water is raised to quench fire,
And suddenly light is extinguished.
Sun and moon press close,
Ever between dark and dawn.
When water waxes, Kan encroaches on yang,
When fire wanes, Li dims the day.
Yin and yang consume each other,
Their intercourse the natural Dao.

The moon itself holds no brightness,
But borrows light from the sun.
Only when the moon reaches its darkest
Does it transform into pure Kun’s body.
Yet within, Kan’s yang is already conceived,
Thus at the cusp of dark and dawn,
The moon may encroach on yang—
Hence the saying of raising water to quench fire.
Kan encroaching on yang, Li dimming the day—
This is the moon eclipsing the sun,
Also called the natural intercourse of yin and yang.

Above, Chapter Thirty-Nine.

Names serve to fix essence,
Characters express the nature’s speech.
When metal returns to its original nature,
Only then is it called the Reverted Elixir.
I dare not speak falsely,
But emulate the sages’ texts.
Ancient records speak of Dragon and Tiger,
The Yellow Emperor praised Golden Flower.
Huainan refined Autumn Stone,
Wang Yang added Yellow Sprout.
The worthy can uphold and practice,
The unworthy must not partake.
The Dao of past and present remains one,
Its discourse reveals all plans.
Scholars, exert yourselves,
Reflect deeply and ponder.
The essential words are plain,
Clear and never deceiving.

Names correspond to tangible reality,
While characters emerge from the nameless.
The "having" is the *po*, its essence;
The "non-having" is the *hun*, its nature.
Only when the Elixir’s fire is extinguished
Can nature be restored and the Elixir formed.
Though the principles of the Golden Elixir
Require careful attention to grasp,
Its meaning is self-evident, not concealed.

*Commentary on the Zhouyi Cantong Qi*, Volume One, concludes.

**Commentary on the Zhouyi Cantong Qi**
*Title: Commentary on the Zhouyi Cantong Qi*
Originally attributed to an anonymous commentator.
Three fascicles.
Base text from: *Daoist Canon of the Orthodox Unity Tradition*, Great Mystery Section.
Collated with: The *Siku Quanshu* edition from the Wenyuan Pavilion, containing Yu Mei’s *Zhouyi Cantong Qi Fahui* (hereafter *Fahui* edition).

**Commentary on the Zhouyi Cantong Qi, Fascicle Two**
*Anonymous Commentary*

The Qian’s firmness and Kun’s softness,
Mutually embracing in union.
Yang bestows, yin receives,
Male and female each requiring the other.
Only when they #1 unite in creation
Does essence-qi begin to unfold.
Kan and Li crown the head,
Radiance spreading and descending.
The profound and obscure are hard to fathom,
Impossible to depict in diagrams.
The sage measures and weighs,
Aligning the primal foundations in sequence.
The four blend into chaos,
Directly #2 entering the void and nothingness.
The sixty hexagrams expand and spread as a chariot,
Dragon and horse harnessed to the yoke,
The enlightened ruler mastering the seasons.
In harmony, they follow,
The path level and without deviation.
Deviant ways are perilous and treacherous,
Toppling and endangering the state.
From the first to the fifteenth day,
Qian envelops Kun.
From the sixteenth to the thirtieth day,
Kun envelops Qian.

chunks.original_text: 月之为物，其初徒有其质，而受阳光然后明焉。 元基者，坎离也。 四者，添乾、坤也。 入虚，谓不用。 舆者，载六十卦而行也。 君即心也。 右第四十一章 君子居其室，出其言善，则千里之外应之。 谓万乘之主，处九重之室，发号出令#4，顺阴阳节。 藏器俟时#5，勿违卦月#6。 《屯》以子申，《蒙》用寅戌。 余六十卦#7各自有日。 发号出令，顺阴阳节，言探取丹药并火候也。 自六十卦而言之，一日当用两卦。 自发火而言之，一日即朝暮用两时也。 故但以《屯》、《蒙》言之，乃《乾》、《坤》后之初卦也，但行之自有进退耳。 故用时前后不同也。 且如半夜子时一阳之生也。 当体一阳而用火； 丑时二阳生，则体二阳而用火； 以至巳时，则当用六数火也。 一数，即三气象一阳爻也。 二数，即三度行二气，象二阳爻也。 以至六数，则三度行六数，象六阳全也。 乃有八变而成卦之道也，反阴符一生於午，则退一数而行五数火； 退至于亥，则六阴全而无火矣。 其日《屯》甩子申者，乃指《屯》卦而言之也，盖上坎下震为《屯》卦。 震卦则初起庚子，坎卦则次起戊申也。 又日《蒙》用寅戌者，亦指《蒙》卦言之也，盖上艮下坎为《蒙》卦，坎初起戊寅，而艮次起丙戌是也。 以是见一卦之各有朝暮也。 直日卦而言之，则六十卦记於十二时之中，其用则各有先后。 但一日无出两时而行火，故总以《屯》《蒙》言之。 右第四十二章 聊陈两象，未能究悉。
chunks.translated_text:
The moon as a celestial body initially possesses only its substance, yet it becomes luminous only after receiving the light of the yang. The primal foundations are Kan and Li. The four refer to the addition of Qian and Kun. "Entering the void" means non-application. The chariot carries the sixty hexagrams as it moves. The ruler is the heart-mind.

**Chapter Forty-One**
When the noble person dwells in their chamber and their words are virtuous, they elicit a response even from a thousand *li* away. This speaks of the lord of ten thousand chariots, abiding within the nine-fold chamber, issuing decrees and commands, aligning with the rhythms of yin and yang. Conceal the vessel and await the proper time; do not transgress the hexagrams and months. *Zhun* employs *zi* and *shen*; *Meng* uses *yin* and *xu*. The remaining sixty hexagrams each have their own days. Issuing decrees and commands in accord with the rhythms of yin and yang refers to extracting the elixir and regulating the firing times.

Regarding the sixty hexagrams, one day employs two hexagrams. Regarding the firing process, one day uses two periods—morning and evening. Thus, only *Zhun* and *Meng* are mentioned, as they are the first hexagrams following *Qian* and *Kun*, though their application naturally involves advance and retreat. Hence, the timing differs before and after. For instance, at midnight, the *zi* hour, when the first yang arises, one embodies the single yang and applies the fire. At the *chou* hour, when the second yang arises, one embodies the two yang and applies the fire. By the *si* hour, one employs the sixfold fire. One count corresponds to three qi manifesting as a single yang line. Two counts correspond to three cycles of two qi, manifesting as two yang lines. By six counts, three cycles of six counts manifest the full six yang. This is the way of eight transformations to complete a hexagram.

When the inverted yin tally first arises at *wu*, one retreats by one count, applying the fivefold fire. Retreating to the *hai* hour, the six yin are complete, and no fire remains. The statement that *Zhun* employs *zi* and *shen* refers specifically to the *Zhun* hexagram, for it is composed of upper Kan and lower Zhen. The Zhen hexagram begins at *gengzi*, while the Kan hexagram next begins at *wushen*. The statement that *Meng* uses *yin* and *xu* likewise refers to the *Meng* hexagram, for it is composed of upper Gen and lower Kan. Kan begins at *wuyin*, while Gen next begins at *bingxu*. Thus, each hexagram has its own morning and evening.

Regarding the hexagrams of the direct days, the sixty hexagrams are recorded within the twelve hours, their application each having its own sequence. Yet in a single day, fire is not applied beyond two hours, so *Zhun* and *Meng* are cited as the general case.

**Chapter Forty-Two**
I have briefly set forth the two images, though I have not yet exhausted their details.

chunks.original_text: 立义#8设刑，当仁施德。 逆之者凶，顺之者吉#9。 按历法令，至诚专密。 谨候日辰，审察消息。 纤芥不正，悔吝为贼。 自初一至十五日，施明於月，故日当仁自十六至三十日，月魄渐以掩明，故日设刑。 右第四十三章 二至改度，乖错委曲。 隆冬大暑，盛夏霜雪#10。 二分纵横，不应漏刻。 风雨不节，水旱相伐。 蝗虫涌沸，草异旁出。 天见其怪，山崩地裂#11。 孝子用心，感动皇极。 近出己口，远流殊域。 或以招祸，或以致福。 或兴太平，或造兵革。 四者之来，由乎胸臆。 冬至象子时，夏至象午时，春分卯时，秋分酉时。 冬至一阳生，则行一数火，至六阳极，则行六数火。 夏至一阴生，则喊一数火，只行五数； 至六阴极，则火数喊灭。 且以冬至之月论之，一月只行一数火，皆於子时行之。 十二月皆然。 如月火自初一至初三早，皆以子时行之； 自初三晚至初五，皆以丑、亥时行之； 自初六至初八早，皆以寅、戌时行之； 自初八晚至初十，皆以卯、酉时行之； 自十一至十三早，皆以辰、申时行之； 自十三晚至十五，皆以巳、未时行之； 自十六至十八早，皆以午时行之； 自十八晚至二十，皆以巳、未时行之； 自二十一至二十三早，皆以辰、申时行之； 自二十三晚至二十五，皆以卯、酉时行之； 自二十六至二十八早，皆以寅、戌时行之； 自二十八至三十日，皆以丑、亥时行之，此第五篇日用之有早晚是也。 至於十二月二阳生，所行二数火亦然。 由是而观，则自一阳至六阳，可默而知矣。 右第四十四章 动静有常，奉其绳墨。 四时顺宜，与气相得。 刚柔断矣，不相涉入。 五行守界，不妄盈缩。 《易》行周流，屈伸反复#12。 与气相得者，如子时一阳生，即可行一数火也。 虽月、时、日三者相并，亦可徐徐而行之，不可连发也。 如欲遽行丑时、寅时之火，适所以为害也。 何者？ 盖二时无二阳、三阳以相应故也。 此所以贵乎与气相得。 右第四十五章 晦朔之问，合符行中。 混沌鸿蒙，牝牡相从。 滋液润泽，施化流通。 天地神明#13，不可度量。 利用安身，隐形而藏。 始於束北，箕斗之乡。 旋而右转，呕轮吐萌。 潜潭见蒙#14发散精光。 自朔至晦，火数皆当合符，不可有过不及之息。 惟於上弦以至下弦，皆混沌之际，牝牡於此而相从，坎离之滋液於此而流通，宜於丑、寅之时，乃箕、斗之度也。 宜探取以应之。 右转者，逆行也。 呕轮，月华也。 吐萌，日华也。 潜潭，坎离之官也。 右第四十六章 品毕之上，震出为征。 阳气造端，初九潜龙。 阳以三立，阴以八通。 故三日震动，八日兑行。 九二见龙，和平有明。 三五德就，乾体乃成。 九三夕惕，亏折神符。 盛衰渐革，终还其初。 巽继其统，固济操持。 九四或跃，进退道危。 艮主止进#15不得逾#16时。 二十三日，典守弦期。 九五飞龙，天位加喜。 六五坤承，结括终始。 辊养众子，世为类母。 上九亢龙，战德于野。 用九翩翩，为道规矩。 阳数已讫，讫则复起。 推情合性，转而相与。 勖毕之上，庚方也。 一阳始生，於卦为震，於爻为初九。 三日哉，生明。 初八为上弦，二阳已盛，於卦为兑，於爻为九二。 十五日，三阳满，於卦为乾，，於爻为九三。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Forty-Three**
Establishing principles#8 calls for enacting punishments; applying benevolence requires bestowing virtue. Those who defy them meet misfortune; those who follow them attain fortune#9. Consult the calendrical statutes, abide in utmost sincerity and meticulousness. Carefully observe the celestial stems and branches, scrutinizing the waxing and waning. Even the slightest deviation brings regret and harm. From the first to the fifteenth day, brightness is bestowed upon the moon, thus it is called "applying benevolence." From the sixteenth to the thirtieth day, the lunar essence gradually obscures brightness, thus it is called "enacting punishments."

**Chapter Forty-Four**
At the two solstices, the measures change, diverging and twisting in complexity. Midwinter brings scorching heat; midsummer yields frost and snow#10. At the two equinoxes, the directions are askew, no longer aligning with the clepsydra’s marks. Wind and rain fall out of season; floods and droughts contend. Locusts surge like boiling water; strange grasses sprout wildly. Heaven displays its omens; mountains collapse and the earth splits#11. The filial son’s devotion moves the August Ultimate. Near at hand, it issues from his own mouth; afar, it flows into distant lands. Some thereby invite calamity; some thereby secure fortune. Some usher in great peace; some provoke warfare. These four outcomes arise from the heart’s intent.

The winter solstice corresponds to the *zi* hour; the summer solstice to the *wu* hour; the spring equinox to the *mao* hour; the autumn equinox to the *you* hour. At the winter solstice, when the first *yang* arises, apply the first-grade fire. When the six *yang* reach their peak, apply the sixth-grade fire. At the summer solstice, when the first *yin* arises, reduce the fire by one grade, applying only the fifth grade. When the six *yin* reach their peak, the fire grades are entirely extinguished.

Taking the month of the winter solstice as an example: in one month, only the first-grade fire is applied, always during the *zi* hour. This holds for all twelve months. For instance, from the first to the early third day, apply the fire during the *zi* hour; from the evening of the third to the fifth day, apply it during the *chou* and *hai* hours; from the sixth to the early eighth day, apply it during the *yin* and *xu* hours; from the evening of the eighth to the tenth day, apply it during the *mao* and *you* hours; from the eleventh to the early thirteenth day, apply it during the *chen* and *shen* hours; from the evening of the thirteenth to the fifteenth day, apply it during the *si* and *wei* hours; from the sixteenth to the early eighteenth day, apply it during the *wu* hour; from the evening of the eighteenth to the twentieth day, apply it during the *si* and *wei* hours; from the twenty-first to the early twenty-third day, apply it during the *chen* and *shen* hours; from the evening of the twenty-third to the twenty-fifth day, apply it during the *mao* and *you* hours; from the twenty-sixth to the early twenty-eighth day, apply it during the *yin* and *xu* hours; from the twenty-eighth to the thirtieth day, apply it during the *chou* and *hai* hours. This is the fifth section on the daily application of fire in both morning and evening.

As for the twelfth month, when the second *yang* arises, the application of the second-grade fire follows the same pattern. From this, one may silently comprehend the progression from the first *yang* to the sixth *yang*.

**Chapter Forty-Five**
Movement and stillness have their constancy; adhere to their guiding line. The four seasons proceed in due order, harmonizing with the *qi*. The firm and the yielding are decisively divided, never encroaching upon one another. The Five Phases guard their boundaries, neither recklessly expanding nor contracting. The *Yi* circulates in ceaseless flow, bending and stretching, reversing and repeating#12.

Harmonizing with the *qi* means that when the *yang* arises at the *zi* hour, one may apply the first-grade fire. Though month, hour, and day converge, the fire may still be applied gradually, never in rapid succession. For instance, if one hastily applies the fire of the *chou* and *yin* hours, it will only bring harm. Why? Because those two hours lack the corresponding second or third *yang* to respond. This is why it is prized to harmonize with the *qi*.

**Chapter Forty-Six**
Between the dark and new moons, the signs align and proceed in accord. Primal chaos and the vast expanse unite; the female and male follow one another. Essence and moisture flow and permeate, bestowing transformation and circulation. The numinous brightness of Heaven and Earth#13 cannot be measured. Employ them to secure the body, concealing form and hiding away.

It begins in the northeast, in the region of *Ji* and *Dou*. Revolving rightward, it spews forth the wheel’s radiance and spits out the sprout’s light. From the hidden depths, the obscure#14 scatters its luminous essence. From the new moon to the dark moon, the fire grades must all align precisely, without excess or deficiency. Only from the first quarter to the last quarter does the primal chaos prevail, where female and male unite, and the essences of *Kan* and *Li* flow and circulate. It is fitting to gather and respond during the *chou* and *yin* hours, which correspond to the degrees of *Ji* and *Dou*. The rightward revolution is retrograde motion. The spewing wheel is the moon’s radiance; the spitting sprout is the sun’s radiance. The hidden depths are the palaces of *Kan* and *Li*.

**Chapter Forty-Seven**
Above the *Bi* constellation, *Zhen* emerges as the omen. The *yang* *qi* initiates its inception; the first nine is the hidden dragon. *Yang* is established by threes; *yin* communicates by eights. Thus, on the third day, *Zhen* stirs; on the eighth day, *Dui* proceeds. The second nine is the visible dragon, harmonious and luminous. When the virtues of three and five are perfected, the *Qian* body is complete. The third nine remains vigilant at dusk, its divine tally diminished and broken. As prosperity and decline gradually transform, it ultimately returns to its origin. *Xun* continues its lineage, firmly securing and upholding. The fourth nine hovers in hesitation, advancing and retreating along a perilous path. *Gen* governs cessation and progression#15, never transgressing#16 the proper time. On the twenty-third day, it guards the appointed moment of the crescent. The fifth nine is the soaring dragon, ascending to the celestial position with joy. The sixth five, *Kun* submits, binding and encompassing the beginning and end. It nurtures the multitude of offspring, becoming the mother of all its kind. The ninth above is the dragon in excess, waging virtue’s battle in the wilds. When the nine is employed, it flutters lightly, serving as the Dao’s compass. The *yang* numbers are exhausted, and once exhausted, they arise anew. Pushing forth the emotions to unite with nature, they turn and intertwine.

Above the *Bi* constellation lies the *geng* direction. The first *yang* arises, corresponding to the *Zhen* hexagram and the *chufu* line of the first nine. On the third day, life begins to brighten. On the eighth day, the first quarter arrives, and the second *yang* flourishes, corresponding to the *Dui* hexagram and the line of the second nine. On the fifteenth day, the three *yang* are full, corresponding to the *Qian* hexagram and the line of the third nine.

On the sixteenth day, the first *yin* arises, corresponding to the *Xun* hexagram. In terms of the pure *Qian* hexagram, this is the line of the fourth nine. The lower quarter is the *Gen* hexagram, called "not to exceed the proper time," meaning that in measuring the slightest weights, one must not go beyond. In terms of the pure *Qian* hexagram, this is the line of the fifth nine. From the twenty-third to the thirtieth day, it is the *Kun* hexagram. Thus, it is spoken of as *Kun* bearing *Qian*. Yet when referring to the sixth five, it is because all *yin* symbols take *Kun* as their master, hence the use of the sixth five. In the pure *Qian*, this is the line of the ninth nine, where *yang* has been entirely consumed and *yin* reaches its extreme before rebirth, thus concluding with the "use of nine."

**Chapter Forty-Seven**
Following the turning of the *xuanji*, ascending and descending, rising and falling. Circulating through the six lines, it is difficult to observe. Thus, it has no fixed position and serves as the ancestral foundation of the *Yi*. The *xuanji* is the instrument for correcting celestial patterns. When *yang* *qi* arises, it moves from below upward; when *yin* *qi* descends, it moves from above downward. Circulating through the six lines, they wax and wane within them, forming the sixty-four hexagrams, which cannot be reduced to rigid rules. This interplay of hardness and softness is why they are the ancestral foundation of the *Yi*.

**Chapter Forty-Eight**
At the dawn of the new moon, it is the *Fu* hexagram, where *yang* *qi* first flows through. Its entry and exit are without haste, and the erected gnomon reveals subtle strength. The *Huangzhong* pitch corresponds to the *zi* month, and its signs begin to flourish. Spreading warmth and softness, the common people receive their constant sustenance.

**Chapter Forty-Nine**
At the *Lin* hexagram’s furnace, the kindling is applied, opening the path to true radiance. The brilliance gradually advances, increasing day by day. The *Dalü* of the *chou* month binds and adjusts the balance.

**Chapter Fifty**
Looking upward, it forms the *Tai* hexagram, where hardness and softness flourish together. *Yin* and *yang* intertwine, the small departing and the great arriving. Converging at the *yin* month, it moves in accord with the seasons.

**Chapter Fifty-One**
Progressing through the *Dazhuang* hexagram, it flanks the gate of the *mao* month. Elm pods fall and return to their roots. Punishment and virtue bear one another, and day and night begin to divide.

**Chapter Fifty-Two**
In the *Guai* hexagram, *yin* has retreated, and *yang* advances forward. Washing and cleansing its wings, it shakes off the dust of slumber.

**Chapter Fifty-Three**
The *Qian* hexagram is vigorous and bright, broadly covering the four neighbors. *Yang* ends at the *si* month, where it interacts at the center.

**Chapter Fifty-Four**
The *Shen* hexagram begins the sequence, treading frost first. The cold spring at the well’s bottom, the *wu* month as the guest of the vine. The guest submits to *yin*, and *yin* becomes the host.

**Chapter Fifty-Five**
The *Lin* hexagram departs from its position, gathering its essence. Cherishing virtue and awaiting the time, its handle lingers in obscurity.

**Chapter Fifty-Six**
The *Pi* hexagram is blocked and impassable; what sprouts cannot grow. *Yin* extends while *yang* is subdued, and *yang*’s name is erased.

**Chapter Fifty-Seven**
In the *Guan* hexagram, observe its measures and weigh the conditions of mid-autumn. Nurturing the young and tender, the old and withered revive. Shepherd’s purse and wheat sprout anew, growing beneath the cover of what came before.

**Chapter Fifty-Eight**

chunks.original_text: 《剥》烂肢体，消灭其形。 化气既竭，亡失至神 右第五十九章 道穷则反，归乎《坤》元。 《恒》顺地理，承天布宣。 此言十二月火，乃年火也。 惟卯、酉、亥三月不用火者，乃火败在卯，死在酉，绝在亥故也，五行中之生金怕死火是也。 故息火以应之。 右第六十章玄幽远渺#26，隔阖相连。 应度育种，阴阳之元#27。 寥廓恍惚，莫知其端。 先迷朱轨，后为主君。 无平不陂，道之自然。 变易更盛，消息相因。 终《坤》始《复》，如循连环。 帝王承御，千载#28画常存。 玄幽远渺，隔阂相连，指坎、离幽远，虽不相通，而实有相通之道。 应度，谓上弦、下弦之内也。 育种者，即阴阳之元也。 阴之元始於离，阳之元存於坎。 先迷者，言离之阴不为先倡，故上弦先育阳之元，阴之育则在下弦焉。 为主君者，亦男正位乎外，女正位乎内也。 右第六十一章 将欲养性，延命却期。 审思后末，当虑其先。 人所禀躯，体本一无。 元精云布#29因气托初。 后末者，即延命却期之事也。 先此谓人之受胎之始，始於无物也。 及自元精一布，而因气托初，则百骸、九窍无不备焉。 还丹之法，正体乎是。 右第六十二章 阴阳为度，魂魄所居。 阳神日魂，阴神月魄。 魂之与魄，互为室宅。 性主处内，立置鄞鄂。 鄞鄂，形貌也。 情主营外，筑垣#30城郭。 城郭完全，人物乃安。 于斯之时，情合乾坤。 乾动而直，气布精流。 坤静而翕，为道舍庐。 刚施而退，柔化以滋。 九还七返，八归六居。 男白女赤，金火相拘。 则水定火，五行之初#31。 上善若水，清而无瑕。 道之#32形象，真一难图。 变而分布，各自独居。 魂之与魄，互为室宅。 以火候言之，则日魂交月魄，而有进退之义。 以坎离言之，则坎男之精气不得乎离女之胎以养，则不能成金丹。 以一身言之，则百骸、九窍、六腑、五藏，非得乎五金之气以为之根本，亦不能以长存。 是知火气神所以为魂，而实质所系皆魄也。 故魂无魄则无所寓，魄无魂则为弃物矣。 故营於外者，为情魄之用也； 处於内者，为性魂之用也。 乾动而直，气布精流，类男子之交合也。 坤静而翕，为道舍庐，类女子之胞胎也。 故刚施而退，则柔化而愈滋。 在修炼之士，九还七返，八归六居，其道亦然也。 九还者，乃三千行满，为九年之数，以象怀胎九月余也。 七返者，乃铅、汞、龙、虎、血、气、神也。 皆欲返於三田。 八归者，乃八百功成。 谓一月八两，一年九十六两，故九年积而为八百余两，以归丹田也。 六居者，乃天地之六子也。 始三年，则育长男长女於下田； 中三年，则育中男中女於中田； 末三年，则育少男少女於上田也。 男白者，坎中之金也。 女赤者，离中之砂也。 则水定火，即前所谓临炉定铢两也。 上善，即离中之阴，自道生一则为坎中阳； 自坎中阳之变化，则五藏、六府、百骸、九窍，莫不各有定居也。 右第六十三章#33 类如鸡子，白黑相符#34。 纵广一寸，以为始初。 四肢五藏，筋骨乃俱#35弥历十月，脱出其胞。 骨弱可卷，肉滑若铅#36。 言人自受胎而至生养也。 纵广一寸，愚尝读《释难经》云：以同身寸为尺，与升、斗之度，有日方寸为两。 则知人於胞胎之始，亦自此一寸而始也。

**Chapter Fifty-Nine**
In the *Bo* hexagram, the limbs rot and the form dissolves. The transforming *qi* is exhausted, and the supreme spirit is lost.

**Chapter Sixty**
When the Dao reaches its limit, it turns back, returning to the origin of *Kun*. In *Heng*, it follows earth’s patterns, receiving heaven’s decree and spreading its mandate. This speaks of the twelfth month’s fire, which is the fire of the year. Only in the third, eighth, and twelfth months is fire not used—because fire is defeated in the third, dies in the eighth, and perishes in the twelfth. This is the principle in the five phases where metal’s birth fears fire’s death, so fire is extinguished in response.

**Chapter Sixty-One**
The profound and distant Dao, though veiled and partitioned, remains interconnected. It responds to measure and nurtures the seed, the origin of *yin* and *yang*. Vast and indistinct, its beginning is unknowable. Those who first stray from the crimson path later become lords. No level ground remains uninclined—such is the Dao’s nature. Change and renewal alternate, waxing and waning in mutual dependence. Ending with *Kun* and beginning with *Fu*, it cycles like an unbroken ring. Emperors and kings inherit and uphold it, its design enduring for a thousand generations. The profound and distant Dao, though veiled and partitioned, refers to *Kan* and *Li*, which are remote yet truly connected. "Responding to measure" denotes the phases within the waxing and waning crescents. "Nurturing the seed" is the origin of *yin* and *yang*. *Yin*’s origin begins in *Li*, while *yang*’s origin resides in *Kan*. "First straying" means *Li*’s *yin* does not take the lead; thus, the waxing crescent first nurtures *yang*’s origin, while *yin*’s nurturing occurs in the waning crescent. "Becoming lords" also reflects the male’s rightful place without and the female’s within.

**Chapter Sixty-Two**
To cultivate one’s nature and prolong life, deferring the appointed end, one must carefully consider the future and contemplate its origins. The body one receives is fundamentally formless. The primordial essence scatters like clouds, relying on *qi* to establish its beginning. "The future" refers to the matter of prolonging life and deferring the end. "Its origins" means the moment of conception, which begins from nothingness. Once the primordial essence disperses and *qi* establishes its foundation, the hundred bones and nine orifices are all complete. The method of returning the elixir is precisely based on this.

**Chapter Sixty-Three**
*Yin* and *yang* serve as measures, the dwelling of *hun* and *po*. The *yang* spirit is the sun’s *hun*; the *yin* spirit is the moon’s *po*. *Hun* and *po* mutually serve as each other’s abode. The nature presides within, establishing its form. The emotions operate without, constructing walls and outer defenses. When the defenses are complete, people and things find peace. At this time, emotions align with *Qian* and *Kun*. *Qian* moves directly, spreading *qi* and flowing essence. *Kun* is still and receptive, serving as the Dao’s dwelling. The firm acts and retreats; the yielding transforms and flourishes. Nine returns, seven reversals, eight reunions, six residences. The male is white, the female red—metal and fire restrain each other. Then water settles fire, the beginning of the five phases. Supreme goodness resembles water, clear and flawless. The Dao’s form is elusive; the true one is difficult to depict. Though transformed and dispersed, each abides in its own place. *Hun* and *po* mutually serve as each other’s abode. In terms of fire phases, the sun’s *hun* joins the moon’s *po*, embodying the principle of advance and retreat. In terms of *Kan* and *Li*, the essence and *qi* of *Kan*’s male cannot be nurtured without *Li*’s female womb to form the golden elixir. In terms of the body, the hundred bones, nine orifices, six bowels, and five viscera cannot endure without the *qi* of the five metals as their root. Thus, the fire, *qi*, and spirit that constitute the *hun* are ultimately bound to the corporeal, which is the *po*. Without *po*, the *hun* has no dwelling; without *hun*, the *po* becomes discarded matter. Therefore, what operates without serves the emotions and *po*, while what resides within serves the nature and *hun*. *Qian* moves directly, spreading *qi* and flowing essence, akin to male union. *Kun* is still and receptive, serving as the Dao’s dwelling, akin to the female womb. Thus, when the firm acts and retreats, the yielding transforms and flourishes even more. For those who cultivate the elixir, nine returns, seven reversals, eight reunions, and six residences follow the same principle. "Nine returns" refers to three thousand completed practices, totaling nine years, symbolizing the nine months of gestation. "Seven reversals" refers to lead, mercury, dragon, tiger, blood, *qi*, and spirit—all returning to the three fields. "Eight reunions" refers to eight hundred achievements: one ounce per month, ninety-six ounces per year, accumulating over nine years to eight hundred ounces, returning to the elixir field. "Six residences" refers to heaven and earth’s six children. In the first three years, the eldest son and daughter are nurtured in the lower field; in the middle three years, the middle son and daughter are nurtured in the middle field; in the final three years, the youngest son and daughter are nurtured in the upper field. The "male white" is the metal within *Kan*; the "female red" is the cinnabar within *Li*. "Water settles fire" refers to the earlier principle of stabilizing the furnace’s weights and measures. "Supreme goodness" is the *yin* within *Li*; from the Dao’s generation of the one, it becomes the *yang* within *Kan*. From the transformations of *Kan*’s *yang*, the five viscera, six bowels, hundred bones, and nine orifices all find their proper places.

**Chapter Sixty-Three (continued)**
It resembles a chicken’s egg, white and black conjoined. A span of one *cun* marks its beginning. The four limbs, five viscera, sinews, and bones are all complete. After ten months, it emerges from the womb. Its bones are soft and pliable; its flesh smooth as lead. This describes the process from conception to birth. A span of one *cun*: I once read in the *Classic of Difficult Issues* that the body’s own *cun* serves as a measure, corresponding to the standards of *sheng* and *dou*, where a square *cun* equals one *liang*. Thus, the beginning of human gestation also starts from this single *cun*.

chunks.original_text: 前言八两者，其定於此乎？ 右第六十四章 阳燧以取火，非日不生光。 方诸非星月，安能得水浆。 二气玄且远#37感化尚相通。 何况近存身，切在於心胸。 阴阳配日月，水火为效征。 此言坎为月，而中有水也； 离为日，而中有火也。 其与阳燧取火，方诸取水，何异哉？ 右第六十五章 耳目口三宝，固塞勿发扬。 真人潜深渊，浮游守规中。 旋曲以视听#38，开阖皆合同。 为己之枢辖，动静不竭穷。 离气内营卫#39，坎乃不用聪。 兑合以不#40谈，希言顺鸿蒙。 三者既关健，缓体处空房。 委志归虚无，无念#41以为常。 证难以#42推移，心专不纵横。 寝寐神相抱，觉悟候存亡。 颜容浸#43以润，骨节益坚强。 排却#44众阴邪，然后立正阳。 修之不辍休，庶气云雨行。 淫淫若春泽，液液象解冰。 从头流达足，究竟复上升。 往来洞无极，怫佛被容中#45。 反者道之验，弱者德之柄。 耘#46锄宿污秽，细微得调畅。 浊者清之路，昏久则昭明。 反者，谓老翁复丁壮，耆妪成妮女也，此道之验也。 弱者，谓自卑者人尊之，自后者人先之，故为德之柄。 污秽者，在己不善之行也。 细微者，精微之道也。 浊昏者，乃和光同尘，埋光铲彩之道也。 此皆养道於外者也。 自怫怫被容中以上，皆养道於内者也。

**Chapter Sixty-Four**
Does the earlier mention of eight *liang* find its determination here?

**Chapter Sixty-Five**
The *yang* burning-mirror draws fire—without the sun, no light is born.
The square vessel of *fangzhu* cannot yield water or broth without stars or moon.
The two *qi*, dark and distant, still respond in mutual transformation.
How much more so for that which dwells near in the body, pressing close to heart and chest?
*Yin* and *yang* pair with moon and sun; water and fire serve as their proofs.
This speaks of *Kan* as the moon, within which lies water;
*Li* as the sun, within which lies fire.
What difference is there between this and the *yang* burning-mirror drawing fire or the *fangzhu* gathering water?

**Chapter Sixty-Six**
Ears, eyes, and mouth—the three treasures—
firmly sealed, do not let them scatter abroad.
The true person lurks in the deep abyss,
floating and wandering, abiding by the compass’s center.
Coiling and bending to see and hear,
opening and closing, all in perfect accord.
They serve as the pivot and linchpin of the self,
in movement and stillness, inexhaustible.
The *qi* of *Li* inwardly nourishes defense and guard;
*Kan* then ceases to rely on hearing.
*Dui* unites in silence,
rare speech follows the primal chaos.
Once these three are secured as the mechanism’s keys,
relax the body and dwell in an empty chamber.
Entrust the will to emptiness and nothingness,
taking absence of thought as the constant.
Proof is difficult to shift;
the mind, focused, does not stray.
In sleep, spirit embraces spirit;
in waking, one awaits the signs of presence or absence.
The countenance gradually grows moist,
the bones and joints ever more firm and strong.
Repel the host of *yin* perversities,
then establish the true *yang*.
Cultivate this without cease,
and the *qi* will drift like clouds and rain.
Gentle as spring’s moisture,
flowing like melting ice.
From the head, it streams down to the feet,
then ultimately ascends again.
Coming and going, it penetrates the boundless,
pervading the vessel’s interior.
Reversion is the Dao’s verification;
weakness is virtue’s handle.
Weed and hoe the long-accumulated filth,
so that the subtle is finely tuned and harmonious.
The turbid finds the path to clarity;
long darkness yields to radiance.
Reversion means the old man returns to youthful vigor,
the aged woman becomes a maiden—this is the Dao’s verification.
Weakness means that the humble are honored by others,
the lagging are placed first—thus it serves as virtue’s handle.
Filth refers to one’s own unvirtuous conduct.
The subtle refers to the Dao’s essence.
Turbidity and darkness refer to the Way of blending light and merging with the dust,
burying brilliance and smoothing away luster.
These all describe the cultivation of the Dao in the external.
From “pervading the vessel’s interior” onward,
all describe the cultivation of the Dao within.

chunks.original_text: 《易》日：离为目，坎为耳，兑为口。 三者各有神存焉。 既言固塞，又言关健，目固可暝，口固可合，而耳则以两手掩之。 又日缓体处空房，谓当寤寐之时，则暝目、掩耳、闭．口、嗜齿，使内常闻风雷之声，火气哄哄然而不绝，则神气自存。 如是则阴邪尽却，而正阳自立。 勤而行之，则和气流畅，而养於内者如此。 右第六十六章 世人好＇小术，不审道浅深。 弃正从邪径，欲速关不通。 犹盲不任杖，聋者听宫商。 没水捕雉兔，登山索龙鱼。 植麦欲获黍，运规以求方。 竭力劳精神，终年无见#47功。 欲知服食法，事约#48而不繁#49。 世之好善者，初无大见识，得一小法则喜不自胜，以为天下无能知者，适所以自蔽也。 右第六十七章 太阳流珠，常欲去人。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Book of Changes* states: "Li corresponds to the eyes, Kan to the ears, Dui to the mouth." Each of these harbors its own spirit. It speaks of "firmly sealing" and "securing the barriers"—the eyes may indeed be closed, the mouth firmly shut, yet the ears must be covered with both hands. It further says: "Relax the body in an empty chamber." This means that during waking and sleeping, one should close the eyes, cover the ears, seal the mouth, and clench the teeth, so that within, one constantly hears the sound of wind and thunder, the fiery qi roaring ceaselessly—thus the spirit and qi naturally abide. In this way, yin evil is entirely repelled, and true yang establishes itself. Diligently practicing this, harmonious qi flows smoothly, and the cultivation within is thus achieved.

**Chapter Sixty-Six**
People favor petty arts,
unaware of the Dao’s depth.
They abandon the proper path for deviant shortcuts,
seeking speed yet finding no passage.
Like the blind refusing a staff,
or the deaf straining to hear gong and shang,
they plunge into water to catch pheasants and hares,
or climb mountains in search of dragons and fish.
They plant wheat hoping for millet,
or wield a compass to draw a square.
Exhausting their strength and spirit,
throughout the year they see no success.
To know the method of ingesting qi,
the matter is simple and not complex.

**Chapter Sixty-Seven**
Those in the world who delight in goodness
initially lack broad insight.
Upon learning some minor technique, they rejoice beyond measure,
believing none in the world could surpass them—
this is precisely how they deceive themselves.

The radiant pearl of the Great Yang
ever seeks to depart from man.

chunks.original_text: 卒得金华，转而相因。 化为白液，凝而至坚。 金华先唱#50有顷之问，解化为水，马齿阑干。 阳乃往和，情性自然。 迫促时阴，拘蓄#51禁门。 慈母育养，孝子报恩。 严父施令，教敕子孙。 五行错王，相据以生。 火性销金，金伐木荣。 三五与一#52，天地至精。 可以口诀，难以书传。 太阳，首也。 流珠，肺液也。 《黄庭经》谓七液洞流冲庐问，庐谓庐额之问也。 惟此一液，易於去人，盖人皆恶之也。 金华者，肾液也。 肺属金，肾属水，子母相聚，马齿阑干之言其多也。 阳者乃日魂也，亦为性也。 慈母乃坤也。 坤为腹，而生五藏之液，故五藏之液能养其身。 严父，乾也。 乾为首，铃须五藏之液上至泥丸官，而后能化之为金丹。 火性销金者，火谓离官之液也，探之叉在下弦； 下弦象秋，位在乎酉，金旺之时也。 金伐木荣，金，坎官之液也，飞之则在上弦； 上弦象春，位在乎卯，木荣之时也。 三者，心、肺、肝也。 五者，脾也。 一者，肾也。 欲成金丹#53，须藉乎此，故日天地至精。 右第六十八章 子当右转，午乃东旋。
chunks.translated_text:
Swiftly obtaining the Golden Flower, it transforms in mutual succession.
Alchemized into white liquid, congealing to utmost firmness.
The Golden Flower first intones—within a brief interval,
dissolving and transmuting into water, its abundance like horse-teeth in ranks.

The Yang then advances to harmonize,
their natures and dispositions naturally aligned.
Yet the pressing Yin of the hour
confines and restrains, barring the gate.

The compassionate mother nurtures and rears,
the filial son repays her kindness.
The stern father issues commands,
instructing and admonishing his descendants.

The Five Phases contend for dominion,
each relying on the other to engender life.
Fire’s nature melts metal,
metal severs the flourishing wood.

The Three, the Five, and the One—
the utmost essence of Heaven and Earth.
This may be transmitted by oral instruction,
but is difficult to convey in writing.

The Great Yang is the head.
The Flowing Pearl is the fluid of the lungs.
The *Huangting Jing* speaks of the seven fluids surging through the central chamber—
the chamber refers to the space between the brows.

Only this one fluid
is easily lost from man,
for all revile it.

The Golden Flower is the fluid of the kidneys.
The lungs correspond to metal, the kidneys to water;
mother and child gather together,
their abundance likened to horse-teeth in ranks.

The Yang is the solar soul,
also called the nature.
The compassionate mother is Kun.
Kun is the abdomen, giving birth to the fluids of the five viscera—
thus the fluids of the five viscera nourish the body.

The stern father is Qian.
Qian is the head, requiring the fluids of the five viscera
to ascend to the Mud-Pill Palace before they can be alchemized into the Golden Elixir.

"Fire’s nature melts metal" refers to the fluid of the Li Palace,
which is drawn at the lower quarter—
the lower quarter resembles autumn,
its position in the west, the time when metal flourishes.

"Metal severs the flourishing wood" refers to the fluid of the Kan Palace,
which is flown at the upper quarter—
the upper quarter resembles spring,
its position in the east, the time when wood flourishes.

The Three are the heart, lungs, and liver.
The Five is the spleen.
The One is the kidneys.
To refine the Golden Elixir,
one must rely on these—
hence they are called the utmost essence of Heaven and Earth.

**Chapter Sixty-Eight**
At midnight, turn to the right;
at noon, revolve to the east.

Exhausting their strength and spirit,

To know the method of ingesting qi,

**Chapter Sixty-Seven**
Those in the world who delight in goodness
initially lack broad insight.
Upon learning some minor technique, they rejoice beyond measure,

chunks.original_text: 卯酉界隔，主客二名。 龙呼於虎，虎吸龙精。 两相饮食，俱相贪便#54。 遂相衔咽，咀嚼相吞#55。 荧惑守西，太白经天。 杀气所临，何有不倾。 狸狗#56守鼠，乌雀畏鹤。 各得其功#57，何敢有声。 子坎午离，右转束行，逆行也。 谓探药飞金晶之事也。 、坎居北而在下，叉欲右转而上升。 离居南而在上，爻欲东行而下降。 卯，木也，龙也。 酉，金也，虎也。 二者所主之名虽不同，然一呼一吸，而二者相会交，相制伏，不能飞走。 西与太白，皆金也。 其·始也，金离子胎，一吸之问，而荧惑得以守其金，故金随荧惑而竟经於天矣。 太白既经天，复能制伏乎苍龙，故六十八篇内日火性销金，金伐木荣是也。 故《黄庭经》日出日入月呼吸存，得之者皆相制伏也。 不服则有声。 右第六十九章
chunks.translated_text:
At the boundary between Mao and You, host and guest assume their names.
The Dragon calls to the Tiger; the Tiger inhales the Dragon’s essence.
Each feeds upon the other, both coveting the advantage—
thus they interlock and swallow, chewing and devouring one another.

Mars guards the west; Venus traverses the heavens.
Where the killing qi descends, what can stand unshaken?
The wildcat and dog guard the mouse; crows and sparrows fear the crane.
Each attains its function—how dare they make a sound?

At midnight, Kan; at noon, Li—
turning right and moving eastward is counterflow.
This refers to the work of gathering the medicine and flying the golden radiance.

Kan resides in the north and below, thus desiring to turn right and ascend.
Li dwells in the south and above, thus desiring to move eastward and descend.
Mao is wood, the Dragon.
You is metal, the Tiger.
Though the names they govern differ, with one exhalation and one inhalation,
the two meet and join, restraining and subduing each other, unable to flee.

The west and Venus are both metal.
At first, metal departs the womb of midnight—
in the space of a single breath, Mars seizes its guard over metal,
and so metal follows Mars in traversing the heavens.
Once Venus has crossed the sky, it can again subdue the Azure Dragon—
thus in the sixty-eighth chapter it is said: "Fire’s nature melts metal; metal severs the flourishing wood."

Therefore, *The Scripture of the Yellow Court* states:
"Sunrise and sunset, moon’s breath stored—
those who attain this all restrain and subdue."
If not subdued, there will be sound.

chunks.original_text: 不得其理，难以妄言。 竭婵家室#58，妻子饥贫。 自古及今，好者亿人。 讫不谐遇，希有能成。 广求名药，与道乖殊。 如审遭逢，睹其端绪。 以类相瓦，揆物终始。 五位相得而各有合，类相况也。 火候文武，物终始也。 右第七十章 五行相克，更为父母。 母含滋液，父主察与。 凝精流形，金石不朽。 审专不泄，得为#59成道。 立竿见影，呼谷传响。 岂不灵哉，天地至象。 若以野葛一寸、巴豆一两，入喉辄僵，不得悦仰#60。 当此之时，虽周文碟曹，孔子占象，扁鹊操缄，巫咸扣鼓，安能令苏，复起驰走？ 五行推相制伏，则不飞走。 不飞走，故能相生。 且立竿铃见影，呼谷铃传响，五行相聚，而叉成丹可知矣。 右第七十一章 河上女，灵而最神。
chunks.translated_text:
Should one fail to grasp the principle, reckless speech avails nothing.
Exhausting the wealth of household and chamber, wives and children suffer hunger and poverty.
From ancient times to the present, countless millions have pursued this path—
yet few meet with success, and fewer still attain completion.
Seeking rare medicines far and wide, they stray ever farther from the Dao.
But should one truly encounter it, the thread of its beginning becomes clear.
Like kindred things shatter one another, so too are the ends and beginnings of all things measured.
The five phases align and each finds its proper union—this is the mutual resonance of kindred things.
The firing times of civil and martial, the ends and beginnings of things.

The five phases restrain one another, alternating as father and mother.
The mother contains the nourishing fluid; the father presides over scrutiny and union.
Essence congeals and form flows—metal and stone do not decay.
With careful focus and no leakage, one attains the completion of the Dao.
Erect a pole and the shadow appears; call into the valley and the echo resounds.
Is this not wondrous? The supreme image of heaven and earth.
Yet if one takes a mere inch of *Gelsemium* or an ounce of *Croton*, swallowing brings instant collapse, unable even to lift the head.
At such a moment, though Zhou Wen and Cao of divination, Confucius of hexagrams, Bian Que with his needles, or Wu Xian with his drums were present—
could they revive the fallen or restore them to swift motion?
When the five phases are made to restrain and subdue one another, they do not flee.
Not fleeing, they can then engender one another.
Thus, as surely as a pole casts a shadow or a valley returns an echo, the gathering of the five phases yields the elixir—this much is clear.

The maiden by the river’s edge—spirit-like, most divine.

chunks.original_text: 得火则飞，不见埃尘。 鬼隐龙匿，莫知所存。 将欲制之，黄芽为根。 媳女，离中五华之气也。 《经》中常言闭。 者，恐其散於外也。 此又非呼吸所求之气也。 惟此气中有真一之水，乃气为水母也。 黄芽者，即坎金之所化也。 二者雌雄相求，故不能以相拾。 右第七十二章 物无阴阳，违天背元#61。 牝鸡自卵，其雏不全。 夫何故乎？ 配合未连，三五不交，刚柔离分。 施化之精#62天地自然。 犹火动而炎上，水流而润下。 非有师导，使其然也#63。 资始统政，不可复改。 观夫雌雄，交媾之时。 刚柔相结，而不可解。 得其节符，非有工巧，以制御之。 若男生而伏，女偃其躯。 禀乎胞胎，受气元初#64。 非徒生时，着而见之。 及其死也，亦复效之。 此非父母，教令其然。 本在交媾，定制始先。 男生而伏，喻坎为男，叉伏而收之。 《黄庭经》日后卑是也。 女偃其躯，喻离为女，爻仰而收之。 《黄庭经》日前昂是也。 如是，而后得交媾之义，故后七八篇日子南午北。 右第七十三章 坎男为月，离女为日。 日以施德，月以舒光。 月受日化#65，体不亏伤。 阳失其契，阴侵其明。 晦朔薄蚀，掩冒相倾#66。 阳消其形，阴凌灾生#67。 男女相须，含吐以滋。 雌雄错杂，以类相求。 施德、舒光，乃男女相须，以类相求也。 惟日魂加月魄，谓行火也。 至晦朔之交，月魄或时掩日； 若到朔旦，则宜施微阳，勿令阴气侵阳太甚，恐有所损。 右第七十四章 金化为水，水性周章。 火化为土，水不得行。 故男动外施，女静内藏。 淫度#68过节，为女所拘。 魄以铃魂，不得淫奢。 不寒不暑，进退合时。 各得其和，俱吐证符。
chunks.translated_text:
The moment fire is obtained, it takes flight, leaving no trace of dust.
Ghosts conceal themselves, dragons hide away—none know where they abide.
Should one seek to master it, the Yellow Sprout serves as the root.
The maiden is the qi of the five flowers within *Li*.
The *Classic* often speaks of "closure"—
this is to prevent its scattering outward.
This is not the qi sought through breath.
Within this qi lies the True One’s water, for qi is the mother of water.
The Yellow Sprout is the transformation of the *Kan* metal.
These two, female and male, seek one another, yet cannot be grasped together.

---

Things devoid of yin and yang violate heaven and forsake the Origin.
When a hen hatches her own eggs, her chicks are incomplete.
Why is this so?
Union was not achieved, the Three and Five failed to merge, hardness and softness parted ways.
The essence of transformation is the natural work of heaven and earth—
as fire moves and flames rise, as water flows and moistens below.
No teacher guides them; such is their nature.
The origin governs all, and this order cannot be altered.
Observe the mating of female and male:
hardness and softness bind, inseparable.
When their rhythm aligns, no craft or control is needed to govern them.
As a boy is born curled forward, a girl lies supine—
they receive this from the womb, the breath of the primal beginning.
Not only at birth is this manifest;
even in death, they replicate it.
This is not taught by parents—
it is fixed at the moment of union, determined from the very start.
The boy born curled forward illustrates *Kan* as male, its lines gathered inward.
The *Yellow Court Classic* calls this "the posterior humbled."
The girl lying supine illustrates *Li* as female, its lines gathered upward.
The *Yellow Court Classic* calls this "the anterior raised."
Only thus is the meaning of union achieved, hence the later seven or eight chapters speak of "child south, noon north."

---

*Kan* male is the moon, *Li* female is the sun.
The sun bestows virtue, the moon unfurls its light.
The moon receives the sun’s transformation, its body unharmed.
When yang loses its bond, yin encroaches upon its brightness.
At new and full moons, eclipses press close, veiling and overwhelming one another.
Yang’s form wanes, yin’s encroachment brings calamity.
Male and female depend on each other, inhaling and exhaling to nurture.
Female and male intermingle, seeking their kind.
Bestowing virtue and unfurling light—this is how male and female depend on each other, seeking their kind.
Only when the sun’s spirit joins the moon’s essence—this is called "conducting fire."
At the cusp of new and full moons, the moon’s essence may sometimes eclipse the sun.
When the new moon dawns, one should apply subtle yang, lest yin’s qi overpower yang too severely, risking harm.

---

Metal transforms into water, water’s nature flows freely.
Fire transforms into earth, and water cannot move.
Thus the male acts outwardly, the female remains inwardly still.
If excess transgresses measure, the female restrains him.
The essence must bind the spirit, preventing wanton indulgence.
Neither cold nor heat, advancing and retreating in due time.
Each attains harmony, together they emit the proof of their union.

chunks.original_text: 男动外施，女静内藏，与二十二篇上德下德同意。 右第七十五章 丹砂木精，得金乃并。 金水合处，木火为倡。 四者混沌，列为龙虎。 龙阳数奇，虎阴数偶。 肝青为父，肺白为母。 肾黑为子，脾黄为祖#69。 子五行始，三物一家，都归戊己。 丹砂，心中气也。 肝属木，故能生火。 金，肺液也，常与肝液为一。 然金本以水为子，故与之合木； 以火为子，故与为倡。 肝为龙，三数也，为火之父。 肺为虎，四数也，为水之母。 肾为金之子，脾乃肾之祖。 三物者，木火一也，金水二也，土三也。 一家者，皆吾身．之所有也。 离管己，坎管戊，功实归之。 右第七十六章 刚柔迭兴，更历分部。 龙西虎束，建纬卯酉。 刑德并会，相见欢喜。 刑主伏杀#70德主生起。 二月偷落#71魁临於卯。 八月麦生，天呈据酉。 子南午北，互为纲纪。 一九之数，终而复始。 含元虚危，播精於子。 束，震，肝也，龙也。 西，兑，肺也，虎也。 南，离，心也。 北，坎，肾也。 当上弦之日以至十五日，则飞坎官之金，自北而南； 当十六至下弦之日，则探离官之药，自南而北，故日子南午北。 然龙常随火，虎常随水，故坎离交媾。 而金木不得以间隔，故龙交乎虎，虎交乎龙，遂日龙西虎束。 大抵金丹专以坎金为主，复终之以含元虚危，播精於子。 右第七十七章 关关维鸠，在河之洲。
chunks.translated_text:
The male moves and acts outwardly, the female remains still and stores inwardly—this accords with the "Upper Virtue" and "Lower Virtue" in the twenty-second chapter.

---

Cinnabar is the essence of wood, and only when it meets metal do they unite.
Where metal and water converge, wood and fire take the lead.
These four merge in primordial chaos, arrayed as dragon and tiger.
The dragon, yang in nature, bears an odd number; the tiger, yin in nature, bears an even one.
The liver, green, is the father; the lungs, white, are the mother.
The kidneys, black, are the child; the spleen, yellow, is the ancestor.
The child marks the beginning of the Five Phases; the Three Substances form one household, all converging in *wu* and *ji*.
Cinnabar is the qi of the heart.
The liver belongs to wood and thus can generate fire.
Metal is the fluid of the lungs, ever united with the liver’s fluid.
Yet metal’s child is water, so it joins with wood;
its child is also fire, so it leads with fire.
The liver is the dragon, bearing the number three, father of fire.
The lungs are the tiger, bearing the number four, mother of water.
The kidneys are the child of metal; the spleen is the kidneys’ ancestor.
The Three Substances are: wood and fire as one, metal and water as two, earth as three.
One household refers to all that dwells within this body.
*Li* governs *ji*, *Kan* governs *wu*—the merit and fruition return to them.

---

Hard and soft arise in alternation, traversing their respective domains.
Dragon to the west, tiger to the east, establishing the weft at *mao* and *you*.
Punishment and virtue meet as one, rejoicing in their encounter.
Punishment presides over subjugation and killing; virtue presides over generation and ascent.
In the second month, the stolen *luo* star arrives at *mao*;
in the eighth month, wheat sprouts as Heaven’s *ju* star occupies *you*.
North at *zi*, south at *wu*—each serves as the other’s guiding principle.
The numbers one and nine end only to begin anew.
Embracing the primordial in *Xu* and *Wei*, they sow essence at *zi*.
East is *Zhen*, the liver, the dragon.
West is *Dui*, the lungs, the tiger.
South is *Li*, the heart.
North is *Kan*, the kidneys.
From the waxing half-moon to the fifteenth day, the metal of the *Kan* palace takes flight, moving from north to south;
from the sixteenth to the waning half-moon, the elixir of the *Li* palace is gathered, moving from south to north—hence "north at *zi*, south at *wu*."
Yet the dragon ever follows fire, the tiger ever follows water, so *Kan* and *Li* unite in marriage.
And metal and wood cannot be sundered, so the dragon couples with the tiger, the tiger with the dragon—thus "dragon to the west, tiger to the east."
In essence, the golden elixir centers on the metal of *Kan*, and in the end returns to embracing the primordial in *Xu* and *Wei*, sowing essence at *zi*.

---

By riverside islets, the turtledoves call to one another.

chunks.translated_text:
Fair and graceful is the noble maiden,
the gentleman’s fine mate.
The male does not dwell alone,
the female does not live in solitude.
The Dark Warrior—tortoise and serpent—coil and intertwine.
Thus do yin and yang make plain:
each must have the other.

Were two women to share a chamber,
though their beauty be as sisters,
and Su Qin send his eloquence,
Zhang Yi broker the match,
unleashing persuasive tongues,
deploying honeyed words,
pouring out their hearts to harmonize,
seeking union as husband and wife—
yet with hair worn thin and teeth decayed,
they would never truly know each other.

If herbs and minerals are not of the same kind,
their names and categories differ.
Their proportions misaligned,
their guiding principles lost—
though the Yellow Emperor tend the furnace,
the Great One hold the flame,
the Eight Lords refine and temper,
Huainan blend and harmonize,
erecting lofty altars,
steps of jade laid beneath,
offering unicorn jerky and phoenix-cured meats,
prostrating in long obeisance,
praying to the spirits,
pleading with the ghosts,
bathing in purity, fasting in reverence,
hoping for some sign—
it would be like mending a cauldron with glue,
or plastering a wound with porridge,
adding water to ice to dispel cold,
or using hot broth to quench heat:
the flying tortoise and dancing serpent
would only grow more erratic.

Since the opening of heaven and earth,
there has been yin and yang after sky and land;
there have been husband and wife after male and female;
there have been hun and po after sun and moon;
there have been qi and fluids after heart and kidneys.
The essential truth lies in the union of above and below,
the coupling of female and male—
only then does the principle of endless generation arise.
How could any single thing stand alone?

In essence, the golden elixir centers on the metal of *Kan*, and in the end returns to embracing the primordial in *Xu* and *Wei*, sowing essence at *zi*.

chunks.original_text: 惟昔圣贤，怀玄抱真。 服炼九鼎，化迹隐沦。 含精养神，通德三光。 津液胜理，筋骨致坚#1。 众邪辟除，正气常存。 累积长久，变形#2而仙。 忧悯后生，好道之伦。 随傍风采，指画古文。 着为图籍，开示后昆。 露见枝条，隐藏本根。 托号诸石，覆冒#3众文。 学者得之，辗椟终身。 子继父业，孙踵祖先。 传世迷惑，竟无见闻。 遂使宦者不仕，农夫失耘，商人弃货，志士家贫。 吾甚伤之，定录此文。 字约易思，事省不繁。 披列其条，核实可观。 分两有数，因而相循。 故为乱辞，孔窍其门。 智者审思，用意参焉。 昔圣贤服炼九鼎，含精养神，与三光 合其德，故能津液充於胜理之问，使筋骨坚致，正气常存而为仙矣。 但文籍之着以示后人，托号诸石，其义颇深，隐而难明，故后学终无所见，不得其门而入。 今魏公着此，使知铅汞之分两有数，火候之相循不乱，学者更宜审思焉。 右第七十九章 法象莫大乎天地兮，玄沟数万里。 河鼓临星纪兮，人民皆惊骇。 晷影#4妄前却兮，九年被凶咎。 皇上览视之兮，王者退自改。 关挞有低昂兮，害气#5逐#6奔走。 江淮之#7枯竭兮，水流注于海。 天地之雌雄兮，徘徊子与午。 寅申阴阳祖兮，出入复终始#8。 循斗而招摇兮，执衡定元纪。 天地之问有玄沟者，乃黄河之水天上来，经流于北方者也。 在人则北方河车，实似之河鼓之星在河边也。 在人则坎男也。 星纪，北斗之分野也。 在人则自北方河车，而直上以达泥丸之比也。 人民，譬则一身之内也。 在人欲飞金晶，则叉震动于内，故日惊骇。 至如晷影前却者，谓坎为月，坎中之阳则为月之晷影。 前却者，却之而不使前。 谓妄，泄也，如水之妄行。 故尧有九年之水，而凶、咎是作。 皇上，即上清真人。 知其不可，故王者当退而．改过。 王者，心神也。 关闭之道，不可不馑。 其或有低昂而不定，则邪气得乘而害之矣。 江淮者，南方之水道也。 在人则为离中之阴，自玉池而出之比也。 其所以桔竭者，则其水流注於海，而不知荫注之道也。 夫天地之一雌一雄，不出乎子坎午离之徘徊而飞翔也。 寅者，火之所由生，亦火之所聚，乃《易》所谓艮之成终而成始者也。 申者，水之所由生，亦水之所聚，乃《易》所谓致役乎坤，又日坤作成物者也。 其可不循斗之所指，以定其用哉。 右第八十章
